## Programming skills
A list of software I use in my research:

* bash (linux console for file handling and archiving)
* emacs (basic text editor)
* git (public version control software)
* python (data analysis tool)
    + spyder (graphical user interface)
    + jupyter (notebook style user interface)
    + xarray (generic multi-dimensional labelled arrays)
    + cartopy (geographic map projections)
    + matplotlib (static plots)
    + numpy (numerical arrays)
    + netCDF4 (read/write netCDF files)
* LaTeX (document preparation system)
* MATLAB (data analysis tool)
    + netCDF/OPeNDAP (CSIRO's interface for importing netcdf files)
    + cbrewer (custom colour maps)
    + m_map (map visualization)
    + TEOS-10 (oceanographic toolbox)
* Microsoft Office 
* R (data analysis tool)
    + ggplot (data visualisation package)
    + pkgdown (website creation package)

## Bash Tips & Tricks

__Note to self__: add these notes down here to the R Markdown file I have in F://

* calculating anomalies in CDO relative to 1979-2016 base period:
```
    cdo detrend -yseassub ifile.nc -yseasmean -selyear,1979/2016 ifile.nc ofile.nc &
```
* saving aliases to save time typing folder directions all the time
Open your favourite text editor; I use emacs:
```
    emacs ~/.bashrc
```
```
    alias emacs='emacs -nw' # opens the emacs text editor without a window
    alias data='/srv/ccrc/data15/z5180028' # alias which links to my data folder when I type 'data'
    alias ll='ls -ltrh' # get more and clearer info about files in folder
    # you can also load modules in bashrc to avoid typing it out everytime you open a new terminal
    module load ncview
    module load cdo
    module load netcdf-c/4.4.1.1
```
Type CTRL-X followed by CTRL-C to close the emacs text editor.

* custom LaTeX command to highlight sections that still need to be addressed:
```
    \definecolor{myblue}{RGB}{49,65,149}
    \definecolor{lightorange}{RGB}{253,219,199}
    \newcommand{\note}{\textbf{\color{myblue}{\fontfamily{phv}\selectfont{\colorbox{lightorange}{\underline{Note:}} #1}}}}
```
To use the command, use ```\note{Text.}``` and the text in the bracket will be blue, bold and the Helvetica font.

* LaTeX command to avoid double brackets when using citations:
```
\citep[see e.g.][]{meinen2000observations, lengaigne2012mechanisms}
```
gives as a result: `(see e.g. Meinen and McPhaden 2000; Lengaigne et al. 2012)`

* restarting unix network printers so they show up in the list of available printers again
```
    sudo /etc/init.d/cups restart
```

## Port forwarding of jupyter notebook to local machine

* Include the following aliases in ~/.bashrc

on LOCAL machine:
```
    alias note_comp_gadi='ssh -N -f -L 8000:localhost:8889 <nci_account>@gadi.nci.org.au' #Forward port 8889 on gadi to port 8000 on local machine
    alias note_kill='lsof -ti:8000 | xargs kill -9' #Kill process on port 8000 on local machine`
``` 
on GADI:
```
    module load python3/3.7.4
    module use /g/data3/hh5/public/modules
    module load conda/analysis3
    alias note_serv = 'jupyter notebook --no-browser --port=8889' #Run jupyter notebook on port 8889
```

* Steps:\
1. Do `note_serv` on gadi to run jupyter notebook. I prefer to run it on the root directory.\
2. Do `note_comp_gadi` on local to connect to gadi.\
3. On local browser, go to localhost:8000/\
4. Copy the token shown in step 1 and get through the verification in step 3\
5. To shutdown, close the browser tabs, do note_kill on local machine, and CTRL+C on gadi to shutdown jupyter notebook server.\
 
 
Hopefully this does not occur to you, but if step 3 does not work, do `note_kill` and `note_comp_gadi` again, and shutdown jupyter server and do `note_serv` again. If it is still not working, type in the command in `note_comp_gadi` but without the '-f' option and try again.
